Award.AwardTitle: ICOB: Dissection of MicroRNA160-controlled Auxin Signalling Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
Normal ovule (a female reproductive structure for producing seed) and fruit development are essential for good crop yield and quality. MicroRNAs (miRNAs), which are small (~21 nucleotides) non-coding RNAs, act as critical regulators to ensure precise control of many biological processes. Auxin, a prominent plant hormone, is crucial for ovule and fruit development. The auxin signal is translated into a robust pattern of gene expression by auxin-mediated release of AUXIN RESPONSE FACTOR (ARF) gene regulators, while miRNAs negatively regulate expressions of ARFs. Previous studies showed that miR160 and its target ARF genes play vital roles in ovule and early fruit development. However, how miR160 participates in the auxin signaling network remains unknown. Using integrated molecular genetic, cell biology, and systems biology approaches, the main goal of this research is to investigate the molecular mechanism by which miR160 and its target ARF genes coordinate to fine-tune auxin signaling to regulate ovule development in the model species Arabidopsis and early fruit development in the tomato. This project will not only provide new insight into the function of miRNA in auxin-mediated developmental processes, but also lead to important applications for improving yield and quality of tomato and many other agriculturally valuable crops. The generated data sets and materials will be made available through The Arabidopsis Information Resource (TAIR, http://www.arabidopsis.org), the NCBI Gene Expression Omnibus database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo), and the Tomato Genetics Resource Center (http://tgrc.ucdavis.edu) for research and teaching.

This internationally collaborative project will have multiple educational impacts. It will provide advanced training for a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student. In addition, the project will promote science education and enable valuable hands-on research experiences in both the US and Israel by developing lab modules and educating undergraduate students as early as in their freshman year, including particularly students from underrepresented groups. Finally, plant biology workshops will be hosted for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 09/01/2017 to 08/31/2018, we performed RNA-seq and ChIP-seq experiments. Using RNAs extracted from pre- and post-meiotic ovules from wild-type, foc, mARF17, arf6 arf 8, mARF6 mARF8, and ett-3 plants, we constructed and sequenced 48 RNA-seq libraries. After a series of analyses, we identified differentially expressed genes (DEGs), which were further used to build gene enrichment maps. The enrichment map generated from data of foc ovules shows that the most dominantly upregulated gene sets are that involved in transcription, sugar transport, hormone signaling, and cell signaling, while the most down-regulated gene sets are that involved in cell wall formation. We found similar results from other plants. We identified 305 genes encoding transcription factors, including 66 AP2/B3/ERF, 36 MDS, 8 AGL, 43 Zinc fingers, 40 MYB, 27 bHLH, 39 NAC, 23 WRKY, 8 ARF, and 11ARR. In addition, we found that cytokinin genes, such as IPT6, LOG1, LOG3, LOG5, LOG8, CKX2, CKX3, PUP14, CRF1, CRF3, and AHP4, were important for ovule development. Interestingly, genes required for cell wall formation plays an important role in ovule development. We also constructed and sequenced 9 RNA-seq libraries using fruits from tomato wild-type and miR160 knock-down plants.

To determine the target genes of ARF10, ARF16, and ARF17, we generated T4 ARF10:ARF10-GFP, ARF16:ARF16-GFP, ARF17:ARF17-GFP, ARF10:mARF10-GFP, ARF16:mARF16-GFP, and ARF17:mARF17-GFP plants. ARF17:mARF17-GFP plants shows strong phenotypes in ovule development, while ARF10:mARF10-GFP and ARF16:mARF16-GFP plants exhibit strong phenotypes in flower and leaf development, respectively. We performed ChIP-seq experiments using ARF17-mARF17-GFP young siliques, ARF10:mARF10-GFP young buds and ARF16:mARF16-GFP young leaves. We are in the process of analyzing all the ChIP-seq data. For ARF17, based on our partial results, we identified 1112 high-confidence peaks. Among them, 354 are present in the promoter regions, 457 are located in the intergenic regions and 283 appear in exons and introns. We have found some promising target candidates.

We have published 7 papers in 2017 and 2018. We also filed a provisional patent. One manuscript is under review and we are preparing two manuscripts to report our results from this project.

This project continuously provides training opportunities for one postdoc, two graduate students and 5 undergraduate students. The PI organized and chaired/co-chaired two general symposia for the International Congress of Botany, 2017. The PI also gave 4 oral presentations in 2018. Postdoc Dr. Jian Huang gave an oral presentation in a meeting. Four graduate and undergraduate students attended local meetings. Two high school students performed research in the PI's lab, and one student published a first-author paper. She also won the Fourth Place in the regional Junior Science and Humanities Symposia (JSHS) in 2017.

Our work will advance the study in miRNA biology, particularly the functions of miRNA in fine-tuning auxin signaling during plant development. The world is now facing more severe problems than ever with continuously increasing global demands for food and energy constrained by resources on the Earth. Normal ovule and fruit development are critical for sexual reproduction in flowering plants. Our research therefore will have important applications for improving crop yield and quality.
